He fell right under their feet! Either he did it on purpose or he was very drunk. The horses are young and easily scared. They got startled, he screamed, and that made them even worse. That’s how it happened!

“That’s exactly how it was,” someone in the crowd agreed.  
“He shouted, that’s true, he shouted three times,” another voice said.  
“It was three times, we all heard it,” shouted a third person.  

But the coachman didn’t seem too upset or scared. It was clear that the carriage belonged to a rich and important person who was waiting for it. The police were worried about messing up his plans. All they needed to do was take the injured man to the police station and the hospital. No one knew his name.

Meanwhile, Raskolnikov pushed through the crowd and leaned closer to the man. The light from the lantern suddenly showed the injured man’s face. Raskolnikov recognized him.  
“I know him! I know him!” he shouted, moving to the front. “It’s a retired government clerk, Marmeladov. He lives nearby in Kozel’s house. Hurry and get a doctor! I will pay, look!” He took out money from his pocket and showed it to the policeman. He was very anxious.  

The police were happy to find out who the man was. Raskolnikov gave his name and address, and, as if it were his own father, he urgently asked the police to take the unconscious Marmeladov to his home right away.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov recognizes the injured man, Marmeladov, and urgently insists on getting him medical help while offering to pay for it.
